messages.message:
To clarify, the PR itself still left us in the "Before" state from the stats :slightly_smiling_face:
The "After" state is from running a very invasive 'rewrite ALL the history in the repo' task, which is ... scary. :smile: But it would be very worthwhile to do, an there is likely a _ton_ of other deleted data that we can write out of the history too. I'll put together a more organized doc to propose such :slightly_smiling_face:
@Cody Boggs ah i see, thanks for clarifying! what is the risks to doing what you proposed, considering it only relates to commits touching `experimental`?

That's the dirty secret of it - it doesn't just touch `experimental`. :sweat_smile:

The super quick-n-lazy demonstration of why this is a destructive change, using our most recent `25.16.0-aihub` release tag:
```╰─> git clone git@github.com:instabase/instabase shrink

╰─> cd shrink

╰─> git log --oneline 25.16.4-aihub | head -n3
eae2a621a3d [AUTO-3] bp prompt suggestion  (#70243)
07836f31122 Release version updated from 25.16.3-aihub to 25.16.4-aihub
47a584439fc Handle ibstreamcb (#70226)

╰─> git <magic stuff to do what I did above>

╰─> git log --oneline 25.16.4-aihub | head -n3
76a857bbab7 [AUTO-3] bp prompt suggestion  (#70243)
39471a4fc44 Release version updated from 25.16.3-aihub to 25.16.4-aihub
e4e231d70c4 Handle ibstreamcb (#70226)```
This is an actual test I just did locally to demonstrate - note that the commit messages are all unchanged, but the *commit SHAs* are all different now. This is because once anything changes "in the past" in a git repo, all subsequent change sets are invalidated and the deltas are recalculated to generate a new history.

Since we have short-SHA strings baked into almost everything we do, it will effectively invalidate everything that uses them - at least, it'll make it impossible to 'go back' to a previous SHA (like what is shown on a certified image tag, for instance)

this makes sense. the following gives me :cold_sweat:
> Since we have short-SHA strings baked into almost everything we do, it will effectively invalidate everything that uses them - at least, it'll make it impossible to 'go back' to a previous SHA (like what is shown on a certified image tag, for instance)

Yea hence my many caveats and disclaimers :joy:

To be fair, we'd be able to rewind to _tags_ just fine - they are rewritten as well and so we'd be covered there. But rebuilding the same _tag_ would yield a different sha to be plugged into <everything> which... _shouldn't_ matter, but at Instabase it does. lol
